entry.title: RSS feeds
entry.content:
What is RSS

RSS is an xml-based protocol for aggregation and syndication of content. It is essentially metadata for your content be it news, blogs or audio files. It includes information such as title, author, and links to your content. The attributes used in the RSS specification or broad enough that they work for any content. All that is needed is for each individual content to have its own location (url). These days practically every news site, blog and podcast has an RSS feed. RSS has gone through several iterations over the years, but the latest is Really Simple Sindication version 2.0. There is also an alternative to RSS called Atom. Because it is based on RSS and features more functionality, some refer to Atom as RSS 3.0. Here is the current v2 specification hosted by Harvard since 2003.

Example

Let’s take a look at an example. The snippet below is an example of a live RSS feed taken from Space.com:

The first thing to note is that this RSS “feed” is written using the RSS v.2.0 specification. It contains a high level <rss> attribute and a <channel> attribute within it. Right after that is some metadata about the website or feed itself, and then an <item> attribute for each individual item, be it a blog post or a audio file. Within each item, you have the <title> of the item and a <link> to that item. These are the essential elements to any RSS feed.

Repositories and Apps

One of the great things of RSS being an XML format is its ease of sharing. There are mulitple RSS repositories online that you can submit your RSS feed to so that others can find your content even easier. Using things like <category> tags in your RSS feed help with this discovery. For typical html websites with article structures such as news or blog sites, Feedly.com is perhaps the most popular. It allows you to copy and paste and RSS feed URL to add the feed, and categorize and organize all your feeds right within Feedly.

Podcasts

Podcasts are the reason I chose to learn about RSS feeds in the first place. I have been listening to podcasts daily for about over 2 years now and I wanted to get a better understanding of how it works. There are 3 big repositories for hosting your podcast: iTunes, Stitcher, and SoundCloud. Just about any podcast you want to hear will be found in at at least one, if not all three of those repositories. Once you have your podcast and RSS feed ready, simply submit it to one of those repositories and any service that has access to that repository can make that podcast accessible to them. Many apps available on the Google Play (I can’t speak for ithe iTunes App Store since I am an Android user) such as Pocket Casts, Beyond Pod and Podcast Addict are able to access these repositories and “subscribe” to thousands of feeds either by manually entering an RSS feed url or through their discovery search interface. Once subscribed, they allow you to download or stream individual episodes, create playlists, group into categories, set automatic updates, and more.

Using RSS in your website

It’s relatively easy to get started with having an RSS feed for your website. If you want full control over exactly what shows up in your RSS feed, you can of course write the entire rss feed by hand. Once you have the structure of the feed, all that needs to change is each individual item to match your content and add a new item whenever you add new content. If you are using Wordpress, you are in luck because WordPress automatically generates an RSS feed whenever you publish your content. It generates RSS feeds for all 4 specifications existing specifications, including v2.0 and even Atom. You can see the feed by going to http://www.<my_wordpress_blog>.com/feed. The default feed is v2.0. I also discovered that Jekyll, a static site generator built on Ruby that I am use to build this site, also includes a ruby gem at installation that automatically populates a feed.xml file when you build the site. For other options, there are several web-based RSS generators that, with some help on your part, try to generate an XML feed as close as possible to the structure of the entered url. Soundcloud supports the same feature if you choose to host the audio files for your podcast there.

Closing

I would be remiss if I didn’t plug in my blog RSS feed, so that you can follow the posts I make about what I’m learning or anything that interests me.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.

entry.title: Chuck: Music Programming Language
entry.content:
ChucK is a music computer programming language created by Ge Wang for his dissertation at Stanford University. He is the creator of the company Smule, most known for its Ocarina mobile music app, which is built on ChucK. He is also the leader of the Stanford Laptop Orchestra, a group that composes music completely with ChucK. Here is ChucK’s website, with download instructions and documentation to get you started. Ge also did a TedTalk about ChucK and its uses, with a small tutorial on how the language works. If you like music and you like programming, you will love ChucK. It is similar enough to other programming languages that if you are already familiar with one, you can be creating your own samples within a few minutes of setting up ChucK and seeing a few basic examples.

Basically how ChucK works is that it has its own virtual machine, that, while running, takes input in the form of frequencies and time durations. The basic structure of a ChucK program is as follows: you create a connection to an output (a speaker), assign frequencies to variables and specify the duration that these frequencies will play for. Here is a simple C major scale written in ChucK:

Here is a sound clip:

coming soon

The first line (SinOsc s => dac;) creates a sine wave oscillator and connects it to the DAC. The next line (523 => s.freq; .5::second => now;) creates a frequency of 523 and plays it for .5 seconds. ChucK reads left to right, so whereas in another language like Java the number on the right is assigned to the variable on the left, ChucK “chucks” (=>) the number 523 to the variable s.freq. These specific frequencies that correspond to real pitches in 440 mHz were easy to obtain. I followed this pitch to frequency mapping chart I found from Peabody:

Let me explain a bit about the durations I chose. Music is measured in “beats per minute” or BPM. 60 bpm means that there is a downbeat every second. By specifying .5 seconds, I am essentially making eigth notes at 60 bpm. There are 3 triplets per beat, so to get the arpeggio in triplet eigth notes, i specfied a time of .333 seconds, or 1/3 of a second. This math can be applied to any tempo with the appropriate calculations. Using that and the pitch frequency chart, is it very well possible to create tonal, “normal” sounding music that one would expect music to sound like. This could even be combined with Music XML (sheet music put into XML format that is used by many music notation software) to quickly produce ChucK code (this is a good topic for another blog post or two).

While that is all well and good, what I think is the most cool and fun part about ChucK is the logic aspect. You can use loops and conditions common to other programming languages to create complex structures. Here is a little more complicated ChucK program utilizing “for loops” and “if statements”.

Here’s what it sounds like:

coming soon

The first for loop that contains two additional for loops is a ⅝ measure that is played 3 times. The math.random2f(700,900) basically means any random frequency between 700 and 900. Then, every other time (given by the if statement) there is either a descending or ascending 4 pattern. This example is structured and will always play out with the same rythm, but because I used random frequencies, no two playthroughs will sound exactly alike. the durations of 200 and 100 ms were arbitraily chose and were not chose to represent any pre-determined tempo.

Another neat aspect of Chuck is its virtual machine. When you click play on a specific piece of code, the virtual machine will continue to play it until you tell it to stop. You can then open another file and play it on top of the one already playing. This allows for really complex layering of music. You can even modify the code as its playing.

As you can imagine, with its logic, randomness and layering in the virtual machine, you can start create really creative and imaginative music using ChucK. It is even accessible to those who don’t understand music theory. You can just as easily pick random frequencies and durations as in the second example and start making music, assuming you know a bit about programming. As I stated in the beginning, if you love music and programming, you’ll definitely love ChucK. I’ve had a blast trying out different sound samples and seeing what clever uses of loops I can come up with.

entry.title: Eldy - Computing for the Elderly
entry.content:
I have recently been put in charge of handling my grandmothers online accounts, such as cable and mobile phone. In thinking about ways of teaching her how to use the computer so she would be able to do things like this on her own, I looked for software targeted towards elders. Sure enough there are a few companies that offer simplified computing experiences for elders. Some of the main haracteristics of these programs include large font, a minimal UI, and only handful of buttons, making things like sending email and viewing pictures just one click away. Link to the article.

The one I tried to teach her was Eldy, developed by a company in Italy. Its desktop, called “the square” contains 6 buttons main focal buttons: e-mail, browser, utilities (which contains photos, documents and Skype functionality), chat room (presumably to chat with others using Eldy), profile, and Eldy TV. The navigation itself is pretty straight forward. For example, you click email, then click either Read, Write, or Address Book, and the rest of the functionality is very basic and easy to understand. I, however, would have liked to see a single “return to Square” button, because otherwise you would have to click “back” several times. Also, the “back” button does not have an arrow, something I think should be used to convey direction, especially since browsers use arrows for navigation.

How well did it work?

I could not get the program to access her outlook email, so email was defunct. The chatroom was empty. The web browser is a simplified and outdated version of Internet Explorer, with unchangable quicklinks to several websites, a subpage for favorites (which I think should replace the quicklinks as the first page, or at least make the links changeable). Eldy TV provided a somewhat decent, simplified UI for YouTube. In other words, it was okay. What it offers is pretty much exactly what I expected it would, and that’s fine, but it fell short in just a few things and is definitely not ready for a full fledged elderly computing experience.

As for what my grandmother thought of it, the problem wasn’t in understanding the concepts of sending an email or navigating the web, her trouble was the ability to operate the computer itself. She barely (if at all) knows how to navigate through her dumbphone, so teaching her things like clicking on text fields, moving the mouse and scrolling pages was beyond her and, I shortly realized, not as intuitive to a complete beginner compared to someone like me whos earliest memories include being on a computer. Thankfully, Eldy does provide a tutorial on using the mouse, which includes showing you how to move the cursor, click on buttons, double click, and drag and drop. I would definitely have to sit with her next time and have her through those tutorials, but I imagine it would take a bit before she even became comfortable with these basics before she could even begin to learn and understand Eldy as a whole.

Overall, Eldy is a great step in the right direction that could benefit from a bit of attention to detail and even more functionality without sacrificing ease of use.

Suggestions

Below are some suggestions and enhancements for Eldy to make it even better:

  • photos should be its own button in “The Square”
  • when composing a new email, the content of the previously composed email should be erased so that the user wouldn’t have to select all and erase
  • smarter directory , i.e. the photos menu shouldn’t allow me to open a .txt document and the word processor shouldn’t allow me to open a photo. To elaborate, it does not, or at least doesn’t appear to, use Windows Explorer. It has its own directory interface which might or might not just be superimposed on Windows Explorer.
  • a “return to Square” button and a back arrow for the “back” button, and the position of the back button at the very bottom of the screen doesn’t make sense. If we continue with the web browser comparison, it should be at the top left. Especially when you consider that once the person using Eldy becomes comfortable enough to transition to using a computer normally, they shouldn’t have to reorient themselves with the position of the most common elements of using a computer (like the back button, X for close, etc.)
  • make it easier to access bookmarks in the browser
  • Better chatroom. This could perhaps be connected to other chat rooms like ICQ or similar so they can at least find a chat for a tpoic they are interested in. (From what I can tell the chat is only for Eldy users, but when I was teaching her, there was no one logged in. I checked again a bit later and at least once person had logged in and posted a message, but because it didn’t have a timestamp, I couldn’t tell when that person posted it).
  • It would be fantastic if Eldy provided Facebook integration. In fact, if there were a similar software that was only for Facebook, something like Facebook for Seniors, would be fantastic. Or even just a “simplified” setting in Facebook. I also recently opened my grandmother a Facebook account so she can see pictures of her family members. They are constantly telling her about photos they post but because she doesn’t know how to use a computer, she can’t view them herself, so we have resorted to showing her through our own facebook accounts. But Facebook is so cluttered it is absolutely useless trying to teach her how to navigate it.
